p: Tree diversity enhances growth and stabilizes productivity at stand level and on individual trees (Jucker et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2016), and it is supposed to modify the impacts of stress factors through “plant-to-plant” interactions. Such interactions may be either negative (competition) or positive (facilitation). According to the “stress gradient” hypothesis (He and Bertness, 2014), positive interactions are more frequent than negative ones in the poorest sites, where resources are scarce.
